fr.reflexe.viewshell.api.http

Interface IHttpServiceCall

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AutoCloseable, Closeable

    public interface IHttpServiceCall
extends Closeable
    Incoming HTTP request/response.

    HTTP calls are processed by implementations of IAddressableService made available to IHttpService via the OSGi Service Registry.

    The default character encoding for text/* media types is UTF-8, even if not specified by the Accept-Encoding HTTP request header. The default media type is text/plain, even if not specified by the Accept HTTP request header.

    By default, implementations of this interface do not restrict the range of supported HTTP methods. However, it is strongly recommended to begin processing by restricting the range of allowed methods to those that can be correctly processed, using allowMethods(String...).

    Note: for the Last-Modified header, the minimum effective value will always be greater than or equal to the creation time of the IHttpService instance. This prevents perceived inconsistencies when older files or resources are supplied to replace default or existing resources. For example, if you supplied a media file "logo.png" then replaced it with an equivalent file (with an older filesystem timestamp), the derived value for the Last-Modified header would instruct caching proxies to display the first file instead of the second (if the file had already been sent). The rule for forcing a minimum Last-Modified value helps avoid such side effects. This rule is applied automatically for the various sendXXX() methods only. It is also applied when you set the value of the Last-Modified header directly.

    Thread-safety: implementations of this interface are not required to be safe for concurrent access. Therefore, processing should generally not be shared between multiple threads.

    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    REFLEXE Technologies

    • Method Detail

      • getHttpService

        IHttpService getHttpService()
        Gets the HTTP service that received the request and that must send the response.
        Returns:
        the HTTP service handling the request and the response, never null.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getContextAddress

        String getContextAddress()
        Gets the unparsed address that was requested, relative to the base path. The address excludes the base path (this makes no difference if addresses are accessed via the server's root path).
        Returns:
        the address that was called, excluding information contained in the endpoint definition of the HTTP service. Starts with "/", is never null.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getAddress(), getUri(), getUrl()

      • createAddress

        IAddress createAddress(CharSequence relativeUri)
        Creates a parsed address, using a "parent directories and file item" idiom. The parsed address excludes the base path (this makes no difference if addresses are accessed via the server's root path). The query string is considered to contain parameters only, and is not therefore considered to be part of the address.
        Parameters:
        relativeUri - a non-null URI relative to the base path. Must start with "/". Directories and files are separated by "/" characters. All other characters will be URL-encoded using UTF-8 (the calling method should not pre-encode characters in the URI).
        Returns:
        the parsed address.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the specified relativeUri cannot be converted to a valid address representation.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        createUri(CharSequence)

      • createUri

        URI createUri(CharSequence relativeUri)
        Creates a URI, relative to the root URI of the server endpoint. The resulting URI will include the base path.
        Parameters:
        relativeUri - a non-null URI relative to the base path. Must start with "/". Directories and files are separated by "/" characters. All other characters will be URL-encoded using UTF-8 (the calling method must not pre-encode characters in the address part of URI, but is responsible for encoding any query string parameters if provided).
        Returns:
        the URI.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the specified relativeUri string cannot be converted to a valid URI object.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        createAddress(CharSequence)

      • getAddress

        IAddress getAddress()
        Gets the parsed address, as interpreted using a "parent directories and file item" idiom. The parsed address excludes the base path (this makes no difference if addresses are accessed via the server's root path).
        Returns:
        the parsed address.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getContextAddress(), createAddress(CharSequence), getUri(), getUrl()

      • getUri

        URI getUri()
        Gets the request URI, that is the basePath combined with the getContextAddress().
        Returns:
        the address that was called, including the base path. Starts with "/", is never null. If for example the base path is "/myapp/" and the address is "/mypage", will return "/myapp/mypage".
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getContextAddress(), getAddress(), getUrl()

      • getUrl

        URL getUrl()
        Gets the full request URL. May be misleading if the HTTP service is running behind a reverse proxy.
        Returns:
        the URL.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getContextAddress(), getAddress(), getUri()

      • getAttributes

        IHttpAttributes getAttributes()
        Provides access to session and call (request) attributes.
        Returns:
        the accessor object for session and call attributes.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getAuthnServices

        List<IAuthnService> getAuthnServices()
        Gets the list of authentication services registered for the duration of this call.

        Authentication services are generally registered by filters when the filter is capable of identifying an authenticated user associated with this call.

        Returns:
        the list of registered authentication services for this call. May contain zero, one, or more services; never null. The returned list is unmodifiable.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IHttpAttributes.addAuthnService(fr.reflexe.viewshell.api.auth.IAuthnService), getAuthzServices(), IAuthnService.getTicketFor(IHttpServiceCall)

      • getAuthzServices

        List<IAuthzService> getAuthzServices()
        Gets the list of authorization services registered for the duration of this call.

        Authorization services are generally registered by filters when the filter is capable of identifying an authenticated user associated with this call, and of providing an associated authorization service.

        Returns:
        the list of registered authorization services for this call. May contain zero, one, or more services; never null. The returned list is unmodifiable.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IHttpAttributes.addAuthzService(fr.reflexe.viewshell.api.auth.IAuthzService), getAuthnServices()

      • getRequestHeaders

        IRequestHeaders getRequestHeaders()
        Provides access to HTTP request headers.
        Returns:
        readable request headers.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getRequestCharset

        Charset getRequestCharset()
        Gets the character encoding used to process the request body, if defined.

        If the client provides a Content-Type request header with a recognized "charset" suffix, then it will be used. However, browsers generally do not include this header in the request. Therefore, when the request character encoding cannot be reliably detected, the implicit default is ISO-8859-1 as per IETF RFC 3875.

        For POST requests, request parameters (if any) are read from the request body and as such you should generally specify the appropriate encoding.

        Returns:
        the character encoding, or null if undefined.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        setRequestCharset(java.nio.charset.Charset), getRequestReader()

      • setRequestCharset

        void setRequestCharset(Charset encoding)
        Sets the character encoding used to process the request body.

        This must be set before attempting to read request parameters or the request body.

        Parameters:
        encoding - the non-null encoding to use.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getHeaderNames

        Set<String> getHeaderNames()
        Gets the names of all received HTTP request headers.
        Returns:
        a non-null immutable set of HTTP header names.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IRequestHeaders

      • getHeader

        String getHeader(CharSequence headerName)
        Gets the value of the named received HTTP header. If there are multiple values, only the first is returned.
        Parameters:
        headerName - the non-null HTTP header name.
        Returns:
        the header value, or null if the header is undefined.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IRequestHeaders

      • getIntHeader

        int getIntHeader(CharSequence headerName)
        Gets the integer value of the named received HTTP header. If there are multiple values, only the first is returned.
        Parameters:
        headerName - the non-null HTTP header name.
        Returns:
        the header value.
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if the header cannot be parsed or is undefined.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IRequestHeaders, getIntHeader(CharSequence, int)

      • getIntHeader

        int getIntHeader(CharSequence headerName,
                 int defaultValue)
        Gets the integer value of the named HTTP header, or a default value if invalid or undefined. If there are multiple values, only the first is returned.
        Parameters:
        headerName - the non-null HTTP header name.
        defaultValue - the default value to use, if the header value is invalid or undefined.
        Returns:
        the header value, or the default value (if the header cannot be parsed or is undefined).
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IRequestHeaders, getIntHeader(CharSequence)

      • getDateHeader

        long getDateHeader(CharSequence headerName)
        Gets the date value (as a long value) of the named received HTTP header. If there are multiple values, only the first is returned.
        Parameters:
        headerName - the non-null HTTP header name.
        Returns:
        the header value, or -1 if the header cannot be parsed or is undefined.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IRequestHeaders.getDateHeader(CharSequence), getIfModifiedSince(), getIfUnmodifiedSince()

      • getIfModifiedSince

        long getIfModifiedSince()
        Gets the date value (as a long value) of the If-Modified-Since HTTP header, if provided with the request.

        When the last-modified time of the requested resource is known and is less than the value of this header, processing can be optimized by setting the response status to HTTP_STATUS_NOT_MODIFIED and sending an empty response message body.

        Generally, this header is most useful for GET or HEAD requests.

        Returns:
        the header value, or -1 if the header cannot be parsed or is undefined.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getDateHeader(CharSequence), setLastModified(long), HTTP_STATUS_NOT_MODIFIED

      • getIfUnmodifiedSince

        long getIfUnmodifiedSince()
        Gets the date value (as a long value) of the If-Unmodified-Since HTTP header, if provided with the request.

        When the last-modified time of the requested resource is known and is greater than the value of this header, processing can be optimized by being stopped and by sending an error response status HTTP_STATUS_PRECONDITION_FAILED with an empty response message body.

        For example, if the client is submitting an update but the server knows that the client is not using an up-to-date version of the resource (due to some other client modifying it since this client received it), then this header can be used (with the appropriate response status) to ensure that versioning integrity is maintained.

        Generally, this header is most useful for POST, PUT, or DELETE requests. It can also be used for range requests with the GET method.

        Returns:
        the header value, or -1 if the header cannot be parsed or is undefined.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getDateHeader(CharSequence), setLastModified(long), HTTP_STATUS_PRECONDITION_FAILED

      • getCookies

        List<ICookie> getCookies()
        Gets cookies defined in the request.
        Returns:
        cookies sent with the request, or an empty list if there were no cookies.
        Since:
        1.0

        See Also:

      • setDateHeader

        void setDateHeader(String headerName,
                   long value)
            throws IOException
        Sets a response header with its date value. The date will be encoded in RFC 1123 format in the UTC time zone.

        Note: for the Last-Modified header, the minimum effective value will always be greater than or equal to the creation time of the IHttpService. This prevents perceived inconsistencies when older files or resources are supplied to replace default or existing resources.

        Parameters:
        headerName - the HTTP header name.
        value - the value for the header.
        Throws:
        IOException - if headers are already committed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IResponseHeaders, isCommitted()

      • createContentType

        IContentType createContentType(String contentType)
        Converts a MIME-type string, with an optional charset suffix, into an immutable structured content type.
        Parameters:
        contentType - a media type, such as "image/jpeg", or (for text types only) a media type with a charset suffix, such as "text/html; charset=utf-8".
        Returns:
        the structured representation of a HTTP content type.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the contentType is invalid.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        createContentType(String)

      • createContentType

        IContentType createContentType(String mediaType,
                               String charset)
        Converts a MIME-type string into an immutable structured content type, with a charset suffix.

        charset - the optional charset. If non-null, the mediaType must be a specific subtype of "text/*" or "application/*".

        Throws:

      • createCompatibleFileName

        String createCompatibleFileName(CharSequence fileName)
        Sanitizes a filename for downloading where the client may have difficulty with Unicode filenames. Transforms text from western alphabets with accents into a form without accents (letters are preserved but accents removed) and without non-ASCII characters (such as the Euro currency symbol).

        Sequences that are dropped (such as non-ASCII characters or characters that conflict with filesystem characters, such as "/" or "\") are replaced with underscores.

        Note: for non-western alphabets, such transformations may remove too much information to be of any practical use.

        Parameters:
        fileName - name of the file to sanitize.
        Returns:
        the filename, after transformation, or null if fileName was null.
        Since:
        1.0

      • isFileUpload

        boolean isFileUpload()
        Indicates if this is a file upload (multipart form).
        Returns:
        true if this is a file upload, otherwise false.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        listFileUploadItems(), getFileUploadConstraints()

      • listFileUploadItems

        List<IFormPart> listFileUploadItems()
                             throws IOException
        Provides access to multipart items (form fields and file uploads) for multipart requests.

        The first invocation of this method will synchronously read all files contained in the request body. After successfully processing the files in the request, subsequent calls are idempotent, that is, they will return the same unmodifiable list. Items in the list are only valid while the HTTP call is being processed.

        If the constraints enable HTTP errors (the default), then violation of these constraints will trigger sending of non-recoverable HTTP errors to the client. Otherwise, an exception will still be thrown, but without changing the status code and without immediately terminating the response.

        Returns:
        a non-null list of items.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the form cannot be parsed as a file upload, or if any other network or filesystem error occurs.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getFileUploadConstraints(), IFormConstraints.isHttpErrorModeEnabled(), getFileUpload(CharSequence), isFileUpload()

      • getFileUpload

        IFormPart getFileUpload(CharSequence fieldName)
                 throws IOException
        Gets a file upload using the name of the field with which it was submitted, if the name corresponds to an upload file field and a non-empty file. It is assumed that each upload field has a unique field name.
        Parameters:
        fieldName - the non-null field name from the form used to submit the file.
        Returns:
        the matching form field, if it contains a non-empty file. Empty fields (such as those submitted without any file being selected) are not returned. When no data is available, or the field cannot be found or is not an upload, then null is returned.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the form cannot be parsed as a file upload, or if any other network or filesystem error occurs.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isFileUpload(), listFileUploadItems()

      • getFileUploadConstraints

        IFormConstraints getFileUploadConstraints()
        Gets file upload constraints, used to apply limits when processing file uploads.

        Modifications applied to the returned object are applied when listing file upload items. This has no effect if the request is not a file upload request.

        Returns:
        non-null constraints object associated with this HTTP call (the same constraint object is always returned for the same HTTP call).
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if file upload items have already been accessed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isFileUpload(), listFileUploadItems(), IFormConstraints.getFileUploadTimeLimit(), IFormConstraints.getFileUploadSizeLimit(), IFormConstraints.getFileUploadQuantityLimit()

      • getAllowMethods

        List<String> getAllowMethods()
        Gets the set of HTTP methods that may be processed for this call, if defined.
        Returns:
        an array of allowed method names, or null if no restriction has been applied.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        allowMethods(String...)

      • allowMethods

        boolean allowMethods(String... httpMethodNames)
              throws IOException
        Defines the set of HTTP methods that may be processed for this call.

        If the HTTP method of the current request is not compatible with this list, false will be returned and an error will be sent (405 METHOD NOT ALLOWED).

        Parameters:
        httpMethodNames - the case-insensitive list of HTTP method names that are allowed when processing this HTTP call. If this is an empty list, it will be interpreted as meaning "all known methods". Specifically, this implies: HEAD, GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS, TRACE, PROPFIND, PROPPATCH, COL, COPY, MKCOL, LOCK, and UNLOCK.
        Returns:
        true if the HTTP method of the current request is compatible with the list of allowed methods, otherwise returns false. Note that when this returns false, in particular when invoked from an IAddressableService, the calling method should normally exit (using the return keyword) and perform no further processing.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the HTTP response headers have already been committed or if an invalid HTTP method name is specified.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getAllowMethods(), getHttpMethod(), isHead(), isGet(), isPost(), isPut(), isDelete()

      • getHttpMethod

        String getHttpMethod()
        Gets the HTTP method of the received request.
        Returns:
        the uppercase method name.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isHead(), isGet(), isPost(), isPut(), isDelete(), allowMethods(String...)

      • isHead

        boolean isHead()
        Determines if the request is using the HEAD method.

        Normally, this HTTP method should not include a request entity body, and should not include a response message body.

        RESTful web service usage: similare to GET except that only meta data should be returned (in other words, response headers without the response message body).

        Returns:
        true if the HTTP method is HEAD.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getHttpMethod()

      • isGet

        boolean isGet()
        Determines if the request is using the GET method.

        Normally, this HTTP method should not include a request entity body.

        RESTful web service usage:

        • Collection URIs: lists the members in an accepted format, with optional extra meta data.
        • Resource URIs: retrieves a specific resource.
        Returns:
        true if the HTTP method is GET.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        allowMethods(String...), getHttpMethod(), getIfModifiedSince(), isHead()

      • isPost

        boolean isPost()
        Determines if the request is using the POST method.

        RESTful web service usage:

        • Collection URIs: creates a new resource or a sub-collection, and may return a reference to the newly-created element. When the resource or sub-collection exists already, then POST should be used to append to or to annotate the existing resource.
        • Resource URIs: creates a new resource using the specified name in the URI. To overwrite an existing resource, the PUT method should be used instead. Otherwise, the POST should only be used to append to or to annotate the existing resource.

        With POST requests, the client is expected to provide a Content-Type request header.

        Use POST instead of PUT to create resources when the server is responsible for determining the URI of the new resource. When POST is used for creation, then the server should return HTTP 201 CREATED and indicate (if possible) the new URI using the Location response header.

        Returns:
        true if the HTTP method is POST.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        allowMethods(String...), getHttpMethod(), getIfUnmodifiedSince(), isPut()

      • isPut

        boolean isPut()
        Determines if the request is using the PUT method.

        RESTful web service usage:

        • Collection URIs: creates or replaces all the elements in the specified collection.
        • Resource URIs: creates or replaces the element identified by the URI.

        When a PUT request is successful, the Allow response header should specify the HTTP methods that can apply to the new (or updated) resource.

        Use PUT instead of POST to create resources when the client is responsible for determining the URI of the new resource.

        Returns:
        true if the HTTP method is PUT.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        allowMethods(String...), getHttpMethod(), getIfUnmodifiedSince()

      • isDelete

        boolean isDelete()
        Determines if the request is using the DELETE method.

        Normally, there is no need for a request entity body or a response message body when using this HTTP method.

        RESTful web service usage:

        • Collection URIs: deletes the specified collection.
        • Resource URIs: deletes the specified item.
        Returns:
        true if the HTTP method is DELETE.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        allowMethods(String...), getHttpMethod(), getIfUnmodifiedSince()

      • setHttpStatusCode

        void setHttpStatusCode(int statusCode)
        Sets the HTTP status code for the response.
        Parameters:
        statusCode - the status code value, normally one of the HTTP_STATUS_xxx constants defined by IHttpServiceCall.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendError(int), isCommitted()

      • getRequestReader

        BufferedReader getRequestReader()
                         throws IOException
        Gets a reader for accessing text in the request body.

        This is primarily used with POST requests.

        The character encoding must be set before trying to get the reader. If not explicitly set, then default values for the encoding may be assumed as per IETF RFC 3875.

        This method is idempotent, multiple calls will return the same reader instance. The reader cannot be rewound back to the start.

        Returns:
        the reader.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the reader cannot be obtained, for example if all content has already been read.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getRequestCharset(), setRequestCharset(java.nio.charset.Charset), getRequestStream()

      • getRequestStream

        InputStream getRequestStream()
                      throws IOException
        Gets a stream for accessing data in the request body.

        This is primarily used with POST requests.

        This method is idempotent, multiple calls will return the same stream instance.

        Returns:
        the stream.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the stream cannot be obtained, for example if all content has already been read.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isFileUpload(), listFileUploadItems()

      • getParameter

        String getParameter(CharSequence parameterName)
        Gets the value of a request parameter.

        For GET requests, these parameters can be provided in the query string, and for POST requests, these parameters can be provided in the request body. Parameters submitted using the POST method with HTML forms can be read in both "url-encoded" format and "multipart" format.

        For multi-value parameters, use getParameterValues(CharSequence) instead.

        Parameters:
        parameterName - non-null parameter name.
        Returns:
        the value of the parameter, or null if undefined.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the Content-Type of the request is application/x-www-form-urlencoded and the method is either POST or PUT and the request entity size exceeds 4MiB. In such cases, you should use multipart/form-data instead.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getParameterValues(CharSequence), getParameterNames(), getIntParameter(CharSequence, int), getIntParameterStream(CharSequence)

      • getIntParameter

        int getIntParameter(CharSequence parameterName)
        Gets the integer value of a request parameter. If there are multiple values, only the first is returned.
        Parameters:
        parameterName - non-null parameter name.
        Returns:
        the value of the parameter, parsed as a base-10 integer.
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if the header cannot be parsed or is undefined.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getParameter(CharSequence), getIntParameter(CharSequence, int), getIntParameterStream(CharSequence)

      • getIntParameter

        int getIntParameter(CharSequence parameterName,
                    int defaultValue)
        Gets the integer value of a request parameter, or a default value if invalid or undefined. If there are multiple values, only the first is returned.
        Parameters:
        parameterName - non-null parameter name.
        defaultValue - the default value to use, if the header value is invalid or undefined.
        Returns:
        the value of the parameter, parsed as a base-10 integer.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getParameter(CharSequence), getIntParameter(CharSequence), getIntParameterStream(CharSequence)

      • getIntParameterStream

        IntStream getIntParameterStream(CharSequence parameterName)
        Gets a (potentially) multi-valued integer value request parameter as a stream, failing if any value is invalid or undefined. The composite value is comma-separated. The stream will only be created if all values are valid integers. Negative values are allowed.
        Parameters:
        parameterName - non-null parameter name.
        Returns:
        the stream.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getParameter(CharSequence), getIntParameter(CharSequence)

      • getParameterNames

        List<String> getParameterNames()
        Gets a list of parameter names contained in the request.

        Parameters submitted using the POST method with HTML forms can be read in both "url-encoded" format and "multipart" format.

        You may safely modify the returned list: calling this method again will provide the original list without any such modifications.

        Returns:
        the list of parameter names. If the request contains no parameters, then this returns an empty list.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the Content-Type of the request is application/x-www-form-urlencoded and the method is either POST or PUT and the request entity size exceeds 4MiB. In such cases, you should use multipart/form-data instead.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getParameter(CharSequence), getParameterValues(CharSequence)

      • getParameterValues

        List<String> getParameterValues(CharSequence parameterName)
        Gets all the values of a request parameter.

        For GET requests, these parameters can be provided in the query string, and for POST requests, these parameters can be provided in the request body. Parameters submitted using the POST method with HTML forms can be read in both "url-encoded" format and "multipart" format.

        You may safely modify the returned list: calling this method again will provide the original list without any such modifications.

        For single-value parameters, consider using getParameter(CharSequence) instead.

        Parameters:
        parameterName - non-null parameter name.
        Returns:
        a list of values for the parameter, or null if the parameter is undefined for this request.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the Content-Type of the request is application/x-www-form-urlencoded and the method is either POST or PUT and the request entity size exceeds 4MiB. In such cases, you should use multipart/form-data instead.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getParameter(CharSequence), getParameterValues(CharSequence)

      • getQueryString

        String getQueryString()
        Gets the unparsed value of the request's query string, if defined. This is the (optional) part of the request URI that follows the "?" at the end of the path in the request URI.
        Returns:
        the query string, if defined, or null. Does not include the "?" character that separates the path from the query string in the URI.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getResponseStream

        OutputStream getResponseStream()
                        throws IOException
        Gets a binary output stream to build the HTTP response, and commits HTTP response headers if necessary. If the Content-Type has not yet been explicitly defined, it will automatically be set to application/octet-stream when invoking this method if the headers have no yet been committed.

        Once obtained, ensure that the stream is closed as appropriate.

        This method is idempotent, multiple calls will return the same stream instance.

        Note: when no response message body is required (this depends on the HTTP method and on the HTTP status), the response stream is not required; when processing is complete, IHttpServiceCall.close() should be invoked.

        Returns:
        the output stream.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the stream cannot be obtained or has already been closed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendData(InputStream, String), sendData(File, String), sendData(IPath, String), sendFileDownload(CharSequence, String, InputStream), sendFileDownload(CharSequence, String, File), sendFileDownload(CharSequence, String, IPath), getResponseStream(CharSequence, IContentType)

      • getResponseStream

        OutputStream getResponseStream(CharSequence downloadFileName,
                               IContentType downloadContentType)
                        throws IOException
        Gets a binary output stream to build the HTTP response as a file download, using the specified name and content type. Appropriate Content-Disposition HTTP headers are automatically added.

        Once obtained, ensure that the stream is closed as appropriate.

        This method is not idempotent, and cannot be invoked more than once per response.

        Parameters:
        downloadFileName - the preferred name for the downloaded file.
        downloadContentType - the content type for the downloaded file. If null, the filename will be used to select the content type.
        Returns:
        the output stream.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the stream cannot be obtained or has already been closed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendFileDownload(CharSequence, String, InputStream), setDispositionType(DispositionType), getResponseStream()

      • getResponseWriter

        BufferedWriter getResponseWriter()
                          throws IOException
        Gets a text output writer to build the HTTP response, and commits HTTP response headers. The character encoding will be selected automatically, based on defaults, or the value of the HTTP Content-Type header.

        Once obtained, ensure that the writer is closed as appropriate.

        This method is idempotent, multiple calls will return the same writer instance.

        Note: when no response message body is required (this depends on the HTTP method and on the HTTP status), the response writer is not required; when processing is complete, IHttpServiceCall.close() should be invoked.

        Returns:
        the output writer.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the stream cannot be obtained or has already been closed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        setContentType(String), sendText(CharSequence, String), sendText(Reader, String)

      • getResponseWriter

        BufferedWriter getResponseWriter(CharSequence downloadFileName,
                                 IContentType downloadContentType)
                          throws IOException
        Gets a text output writer to build the HTTP response as a file download, using the specified name and content type. Appropriate Content-Disposition HTTP headers are automatically added. The character encoding will be selected automatically, based on defaults, or the value of the HTTP Content-Type header.

        Once obtained, ensure that the writer is closed as appropriate.

        This method is not idempotent, and cannot be invoked more than once per response.

        Parameters:
        downloadFileName - the preferred name for the downloaded file.
        downloadContentType - the content type for the downloaded file. If null, the filename will be used to select the content type.
        Returns:
        the output stream.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the writer cannot be obtained or has already been closed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendFileDownload(CharSequence, String, InputStream), setDispositionType(DispositionType), getResponseWriter()

      • isCommitted

        boolean isCommitted()
        Determines whether HTTP headers have been sent to the client. HTTP headers are considered committed as soon as any attempt to add content to the response body is made.
        Returns:
        true if HTTP headers have been finalized for this request or false if they may still be modified.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isResponseClosed()

      • isRequestClosed

        boolean isRequestClosed()
        Determines whether the HTTP request body has been read.

        If the request body has been read once, it cannot be read again. However, this restriction does not apply to headers or other request parameters.

        Returns:
        true if the request body has been read either explicitly using a reader or a getRequestStream(), or implicitly using any of the "getParameter" method variants. Returns false if the request body has not yet been accessed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getRequestReader(), getRequestStream(), getParameterNames(), getParameter(CharSequence), getParameterValues(CharSequence), close()

      • isResponseClosed

        boolean isResponseClosed()
        Determines whether the HTTP headers and the response body have been sent.
        Returns:
        true if HTTP headers and response body have been finalized for this request or false if modifications are still possible for the response body (for the response headers, use isCommitted()).
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isCommitted(), close()

      • close

        void close()
    throws IOException
        Stops input and output processing for the request and the response, and should be used to end processing for services that do not produce a response message body.

        Invoking close() does not normally interrupt program execution flow, therefore care should be taken to return from the calling method as appropriate after this method is called.

        Note: there is no need to invoke this method if the when using any of the sendXXX methods or when close() has already been invoked on either the response stream or the response writer.

        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable
        Specified by:
        close in interface Closeable
        Throws:
        IOException - if an error occurs when closing resources.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isRequestClosed(), isResponseClosed()

      • setExpires

        void setExpires(long timeMillis)
         throws IOException
        Sets the HTTP Expires header value.

        When defined, then this header value must be specified as a date; other formats (such as specifying 0) are invalid and clients are expected to consider such headers as invalid, meaning "already expired".

        Clients can use the value of this header to avoid contacting the server to revalidate content; in other words, if a client has content that has not expired, then it can re-use the cached content without contacting the server to check if a more recent version is available.

        Clients will ignore this header value if a Cache-Control: max-age=delta-seconds directive is specified.

        Parameters:
        timeMillis - the expiry time expressed as a number of milliseconds since the Unix Epoch time.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the header value cannot be set (invalid value, or too late).
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isCommitted(), setLastModified(long)

      • setLastModified

        void setLastModified(long timeMillis)
              throws IOException
        Sets the HTTP Last-Modified header value.

        As described by the class description of IHttpServiceCall, this time value may be forced to be equal to the time of startup of the HTTP service (if less than this value), to avoid HTTP caching issues that may occur when inconsistencies occurs between actual file timestamps and timestamps on resources embedded in ZIP files or OSGi bundles (dates may become inconsistent when deploying on a new server, for example).

        When this information is known, consider also using getIfModifiedSince() (and possibly getIfUnmodifiedSince()) to optimize communication with the client and usage of server-side resources.

        The last modified time should take into account the time of the most recent modification to any data or component used to produce the response, and the session creation time in the case of personalized responses (to avoid a browser displaying cached data for a previously-authenticated user). Components include template files and template attributes, localization dictionaries, and data includes any record used (directly or indirectly using relationships or composition) to produce the response.

        Parameters:
        timeMillis - the last modified time to associate with the response. Note that if this is based on a time value read from a resource (database record, or a string without timezone information), then it is your responsability to ensure that the millisecond time value is aligned with UTC.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the header value cannot be set (invalid value, or too late).
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isCommitted(), setExpires(long), getIfModifiedSince(), getIfUnmodifiedSince()

        Parameters:

        Throws:

                 throws IOException

        Parameters:

      • setContentLength

        void setContentLength(long contentLength)
               throws IOException
        Defines the value of the HTTP Content-Length header assigned to the response.

        This is normally defined automatically. Generally, it is only useful to specify a value when processing HEAD requests. If used with any other method, setting this value may corrupt the response (especially if implicit automatic compression is enabled).

        Parameters:
        contentLength - the size of the response body, in bytes.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the response is closed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        Content-Length, isHead(), noAutoCompress()

      • encodeUrl

        String encodeUrl(CharSequence url)
        Appends the session ID to the specified URL, enabling session tracking when cookies are not enabled. Generally, this method should be called for all emitted URLs.

        If cookie-based session tracking is enabled, and if can be determined that the client does not require URL rewriting, then the URL may be returned unchanged.

        Parameters:
        url - the URL to encode.
        Returns:
        the encoded URL, unless encoding is not required, or null if url is null.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IHttpAttributes.getSessionId()

      • sendError

        void sendError(int errorStatusCode)
        throws IOException
        Sends a HTTP error code to the client and terminates the response.

        Note: this does not interrupt the processing within the calling method. You must ensure that your own code exits cleanly after calling this method.

        Parameters:
        errorStatusCode - any current or future HTTP error code in the (inclusive) range [400..1000].
        Throws:
        IOException - if the code is out of range or if headers have already been committed to the response.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isCommitted()

      • sendBasicChallenge

        void sendBasicChallenge(CharSequence realm)
                 throws IOException
        Sends a basic authentication challenge to the client.

        This includes sending the 401 HTTP status code and the WWW-Authenticate response header. The operation will therefore fail if headers have already been committed. It will then close the response (so, invoke return after invoking this method, as no further processing should be performed for the request).

        Note: the basic authentication protocol is often used and a standard part of the HTTP specifications (refer to RFC-2617), however it has several limitations:

        1. It is vulnerable to replay attacks, where an attacker can successfully authenticate by copying the information sent by a client in a previous request.
        2. It is vulnerable to packet analysis, where an attacker can extract usernames and passwords sent by a client, unless SSL/TLS encryption is used with a trusted certificate. As users often use the same credentials for multiple resources, this makes it easier for an attacker to guess passwords for other protected resources.
        3. The character encoding used for authentication is undefined, therefore most browsers implement support for non-ASCII characters in different (and incompatible) ways. This is even more problematic when the client uses a character encoding that does not include ASCII characters. Therefore, ISO-8859-1 is assumed as the most compatible compromise, however it may lead to unexpected results with some browsers.
        Parameters:
        realm - the realm string used to help the client determine which authentication principal and credentials it should provide. Must be non-null and non-empty.
        Throws:
        IOException - if headers have already been committed.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isCommitted(), IRequestHeaders.getBasicAuthentication()

      • noAutoCompress

        void noAutoCompress()
             throws IOException
        Disables implicit compression of the response, without preventing explicit compression.

        Implicit compression is applied when the request header Accept-Encoding is set with a supported compression algorithm (such as gzip, compress, or deflate, with an optional x- prefix). It is also applied if the response header Content-Encoding is explicitly set with a supported algorithm.

        After disabling implicit compression, it cannot be enabled again for the current response.

        Implicit compression will not be applied when the Content-Type of the response suggests that compression is likely to be inefficient. For example, image formats such as image/jpeg and image/png are not automatically compressed (but image/svg+xml is normally automatically compressed). Compressed file formats such as zip, gz, and tgz are also excluded from implicit compression when sent with default MIME type information (but tar is implicitly compressed).

        Throws:
        IOException - if headers are already committed.
        Since:
        1.0

      • noCache

        void noCache()
      throws IOException
        Sets the Expires and Cache-Control response headers such that clients are instructed not to keep cached copies of the response.
        Throws:
        IOException - if headers are already committed.
        Since:
        1.0

      • sendData

        void sendData(IPath source)
       throws IOException
        Builds and sends the response based on data contained by the specified source. This will attempt to set appropriate headers, such as the Content-Type, automatically, before writing data to the response, then closing the response.
        Parameters:
        source - non-null source for data.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the response is in an invalid state, or if the source cannot provide the data to be written to the response.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        IPath.getMediaType(), sendData(java.io.File), sendData(java.io.InputStream), sendData(fr.reflexe.viewshell.api.fs.IPath, String)

      • sendData

        void sendData(IPath source,
              String usingContentType)
       throws IOException
        Builds and sends the response based on data contained by the specified source. This will attempt to set appropriate headers, before writing data to the response, then closing the response.
        Parameters:
        source - non-null source for data.
        usingContentType - value of the HTTP Content-Type header to use. If null then a default binary content type will be used, if starting with the pattern text/* then a default character set will be used (unless the charset is specified as part of the header value).
        Throws:
        IOException - if the response is in an invalid state, or if the source cannot provide the data to be written to the response.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        createContentType(String)

       throws IOException

        Parameters:

        usingContentType - value of the HTTP Content-Type header to use. If null then a default binary content type will be used, if starting with the pattern text/* then a default character set will be used (unless the charset is specified as part of the header value), unless the header is already defined.

      • setDispositionType

        void setDispositionType(DispositionType dispositionType)
                 throws IOException
        Sets the content disposition type to use for sending a file.

        The disposition type, if defined using this method, will be applied automatically by other methods defined by this interface that automatically apply the Content-Disposition response header. These methods will default to attachment if the disposition type has not been defined.

        Parameters:
        dispositionType - the required disposition type, or null (to use the default disposition type).
        Throws:
        IOException - if the disposition cannot be set (when the response has already been committed).
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getResponseStream(CharSequence, IContentType), getResponseWriter(CharSequence, IContentType), sendFileDownload(CharSequence, String, File), sendFileDownload(CharSequence, String, InputStream), sendFileDownload(CharSequence, String, IPath)

      • sendFileDownload

        void sendFileDownload(CharSequence usingFileName,
                      String usingContentType,
                      File source)
               throws IOException
        Sends a file as a download to the client.

        When a filename is specified, all control characters (ASCII codes less than 32), and the reserved characters "\", "/", ":", ";", "|", "<", ">", """ (double-quote), "?", and "*" are all automatically stripped.

        Parameters:
        usingFileName - the file name to use. If null, then the name of the specified source will be used.
        usingContentType - the Content-Type of the file. If null, then the name of the file will be used to attempt to determine the content type.
        source - the non-null file to send.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an error occurs sending the file.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        createContentType(String), createCompatibleFileName(CharSequence), setDispositionType(DispositionType)

      • sendFileDownload

        void sendFileDownload(CharSequence usingFileName,
                      String usingContentType,
                      IPath source)
               throws IOException
        Sends a file (read from a virtual path) as a download to the client.

        When a filename is specified, all control characters (ASCII codes less than 32), and the reserved characters "\", "/", ":", ";", "|", "<", ">", """ (double-quote), "?", and "*" are all automatically stripped.

        Parameters:
        usingFileName - the file name to use. If null, then the name of the specified source will be used.
        usingContentType - the Content-Type of the file. If null, then the MIME type of the source will be used to attempt to determine the content type.
        source - the non-null virtual path of the data to send.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an error occurs sending the file.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        createContentType(String), createCompatibleFileName(CharSequence), setDispositionType(DispositionType)

      • sendFileDownload

        void sendFileDownload(CharSequence usingFileName,
                      String usingContentType,
                      InputStream source)
               throws IOException
        Sends a file (read from an input stream) as a download to the client.

        To compute the Content-Length of the file, it may be fully read into either a file or memory buffer (and not streamed directly). In all cases, invoking this method will cause the stream to be closed.

        When a filename is specified, all control characters (ASCII codes less than 32), and the reserved characters "\", "/", ":", ";", "|", "<", ">", """ (double-quote), "?", and "*" are all automatically stripped.

        Parameters:
        usingFileName - the file name to use. If null, then the content type (if specified) will be used to generate a default file name with an associated extension (if neither are specified, a default name will still be generated, but with a generic ".data" file name extension). source will be used.
        usingContentType - the Content-Type of the file. If null, then the name of the file (if specified) will be used to attempt to determine the content type (if neither are specified, a default application/octet-stream content type will be used), unless the header is already defined.
        source - the non-null stream of data to send as a file.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an error occurs sending the file.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        createContentType(String), createCompatibleFileName(CharSequence), getResponseStream(CharSequence, IContentType), getResponseWriter(CharSequence, IContentType), setDispositionType(DispositionType)

      • sendText

        void sendText(CharSequence source)
       throws IOException
        Sends a String, StringBuilder, or other implementation of CharSequence as the response body, and closes the response. Any appropriate headers, such as Content-Type (including character encoding) are set automatically if not specifically defined before calling the method.

        For example, the following code:

        call.sendText("Hello World!");

        ...is sufficient to create a response (with "text/plain;charset=UTF-8" as the Content-Type) and send it to the client with "Hello World!" as the response body.

        The response is closed automatically after calling this method.

        Parameters:
        source - non-null text to send to the client.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the source is undefined or if the response cannot be sent (for example, if the response is already closed).
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendText(CharSequence, String)

      • sendText

        void sendText(CharSequence source,
              String usingContentType)
       throws IOException
        Sends a String, StringBuilder, or other implementation of CharSequence as the response body using a specific Content-Type, and closes the response.
        Parameters:
        source - non-null text to send to the client.
        usingContentType - the text/* media type, with an optional ";charset=XXX" suffix. If no character encoding is specified, one will be automatically selected.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the source is undefined, or if the response cannot be sent (for example, if the response is already closed), or if usingContentType is not null and is of an unsupported type.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendText(java.io.Reader, String)

        Since:
        1.0

        sendText(java.io.Reader, String)

      • sendRedirect

        void sendRedirect(CharSequence uri)
           throws IOException
        Sends a redirect status to initiate a client-side URL redirection.

        You cannot send a redirection request after sending an error or after committing headers.

        Note:

        • calling this method implicitly closes resources used for request and response processing
        • calling this method does not stop processing in the method that calls it, so ensure that processing flow is stopped as appropriate.
        • when deployed with a reverse proxy (such as Apache HTTPD or Microsoft IIS), ensure that redirection addresses are appropriate and correctly processed
        Parameters:
        uri - a non-null relative or absolute (full) URL address. "/" is relative to the hostname, which may or may not be the same as the base path for the application.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the redirect address format is invalid or if it is too late to send the redirection status.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendRedirect(IAddress), sendRedirect(URI), IHttpEndPoint.getBasePath()

      • sendRedirect

        void sendRedirect(IAddress uri)
           throws IOException
        Sends a redirect status to initiate a client-side URL redirection, relative to the base path of this server application.

        You cannot send a redirection request after sending an error or after committing headers.

        Note:

        • calling this method implicitly closes resources used for request and response processing
        • calling this method does not stop processing in the method that calls it, so ensure that processing flow is stopped as appropriate.
        • when deployed with a reverse proxy (such as Apache HTTPD or Microsoft IIS), ensure that redirection addresses are appropriate and correctly processed
        • automatically appends the session identifier to the URL, if necessary
        Parameters:
        uri - a non-null address, relative to the base path.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the redirection cannot be sent.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendRedirect(CharSequence), sendRedirect(URI), createAddress(CharSequence), IHttpEndPoint.getBasePath()

      • sendRedirect

        void sendRedirect(URI uri)
           throws IOException
        Sends a redirect status to initiate a client-side URL redirection.

        You cannot send a redirection request after sending an error or after committing headers.

        Note:

        • calling this method implicitly closes resources used for request and response processing
        • calling this method does not stop processing in the method that calls it, so ensure that processing flow is stopped as appropriate.
        • when deployed with a reverse proxy (such as Apache HTTPD or Microsoft IIS), ensure that redirection addresses are appropriate and correctly processed
        • automatically appends the session identifier to the URL, if necessary, if a relative URI is specified.
        Parameters:
        uri - a non-null relative or absolute (full) URL address. "/" is relative to the hostname, which may or may not be the same as the base path for the application.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the redirection cannot be sent.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        sendRedirect(CharSequence), sendRedirect(IAddress), createUri(CharSequence)
